def.dt: :a person who does business for another person :a person who acts on behalf of another They worked with a travel agent to plan their vacation. The actor got a starring role through his (theatrical) agent. a literary agent [=a person who helps writers to get their works published] see also free agent insurance agent press agent real estate agent
:a person who tries to get secret information about another country, government, etc. :spy secret agent a government agent see also double agent special agent
:a person or thing that causes something to happen They view themselves as agents of social change. [=people who cause social change to happen]

:something (such as a chemical) that is used to produce a particular effect or result The drug is an effective agent for the treatment of asthma. the main flavoring agent in the drink Cornstarch is used as a thickening agent in sauces.
:a person employed to encourage people to break the law so that they can be arrested The government used agents provocateurs to try to undermine the opposition party.
:a spy who pretends to spy for one government while actually spying for another He was secretly working as a double agent for the Americans during the war.
:a person who is able to act freely without being controlled by someone else
:a professional athlete (such as a baseball player) who is free to sign a contract to play for any team

utxt.vi: an athlete who has become eligible for free agency

def.dt: :a person whose job is to provide people with insurance called also insurance broker
:a person whose job is to give information about an important or famous person or organization to news reporters
:a person in the business of selling land and buildings called also (Brit) estate agent
:a person who tries to get secret information about another country, government, etc. He was accused of being a secret agent for a foreign government.
:an agent who works for the FBI
